title: The Beauty of a Crossvine | Architectural Digest
text: To revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories To revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved stories To revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories To revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved stories By Mitchell Owens Tightly wound gardens—all straight lines and assiduous manicuring—can be a thing of beauty, but adding a note or two of uncontrolled madness gives perfection a dash of panache. Bignonia capreolata, a.k.a. crossvine, is a wild-mannered wonder that takes the edge off. It swirls, it grapples, it goes off-piste, all the while pumping out clusters of fleshy, horn-shaped blooms in shades of cinnabar to persimmon.
